Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
@jl777c  a short time ago you mentioned there was an assetchain parameter/feature for a single address receiving a "fee".
a)  is this testable in any branch?
b)  is the "fee" a set amount, or a "%" of the transaction.
c)  this "fee" - can it currently be a variable amount?  if not, do you see this as potentially do-able.

The use case is a franchise setup where the franchisor receives a "fee".  If the case for (c) can be implemented, the use case would be that the KMD value vs the BTC value vs the $ value  would be calculated by some data-feed (centralised or decentralised).

Failing that, would this be more useful for cryptoconditions looking forward?

Cheers

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
@grewalsatinder from my limited understanding atm, ILP is streams of characters.  CC is defined in ASN.1 notation (similar to SNMP MIBS and HL7 medical devices protocols).

https://interledger.org/rfcs/0027-interledger-protocol-4/

So in that page, you'll see that `amount` and `expiresAt`  are "fixed length fields".  Each field has it's identifier and type.

As a telecommunications example, using my CSTA knowledge: in ASN.1
```
0x02 = Integer

Codes:
0x80=Device
0x30=Sequence
```
And the format of a CSTA protocol string is:  Integer + Sequence + Length + Device + Length + DeviceAsString + More protocol functions.

e.g.
```
0x02 0x30 0x0c 0x80 0x0a 0x30 0x34 0x36 0x38 0x34 0x38 0x35 0x33 0x38 0x35 .........
```
In this case the length `0x0b` of characters that follow.  0x80.....
`0x80` + length of 10 chars counted in base16, then my old mobile phone number (0468485385) in hex ascii codes.

So in this example CSTA protocol can be decoded by any language that reads those bytes like that.

I presume, similarly with SNMP and our KMD-CC ILP stuff.

Hope this makes sense, and if you can confirm @libscott @libscott

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: as for dPoW requirements, i'm not familiar with how CC and dPoW are both required.  I think in the case of scaling across assetchains this was the way it was designed for many chains federating.

Author: libscott#8867
Content: Hi, If youre familiar with bitcoin‚Äôs scriptpubkey and scriptsig, CC provides a condition and a fulfillment which are similar. The first is a cryptographic lock of some kind, the second provides the data which unlocks. CC is a protocol for encoding trees of conditions, which would be a bit impractical to implement in bitcoin‚Äôs scripting language. The condition types are ed25519, secp256k1, preimage, message prefix and threshold (n of m).

Author: libscott#8867
Content: In addition we implemented an EVAL type so we can extend it with custom functions, to verify cross chain proofs and whatnot.

Author: libscott#8867
Content: In order for other chains to join our proof system we would need to be notarising them. And implement their transaction type in our code, or vice versa

Author: libscott#8867
Content: Youre quite limited in what you can do with CC, mainly because of the bitcoin data structure. UTXOs arent a good way to encode an application state, really. But what you can do is copy a payout vector from one chain to another, so you can do cross chain transactions.

Author: libscott#8867
Content: As for interop, the interledger protocol is an interchain atomic swap protocol that uses marketmakers. Having CC should make it easier for us to become part of that network.

Author: libscott#8867
Content: Crypto-Conditions libraries abstract away the ASN1 part so you don tneed to worry about it; This is the interface in libcryptoconditions which I made for Komodo: https://github.com/libscott/libcryptoconditions/blob/master/include/cryptoconditions.h

Author: libscott#8867
Content: if you need any help to make prototocols let me know, hope this answers questions @Mylo @grewalsatinder

Author: libscott#8867
Content: i'd like if blockchains could be like event loops, where you have a setTimeout function, but i havnt seen that yet üòÑ

Author: libscott#8867
Content: for the poker protocol we implemented a CC function which was: (EITHER (5 of 5 sigs) OR (1 of 5 sigs AND (timeout AND EVAL("poker"))). So either everyone agreed, or a timeout had to occur and an evaluation function over posted gamestates had to return a certain value...

Author: libscott#8867
Content: the question is what would we like to be able to do? üòÉ

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: How about something simple like escrow for 10 blocks and refund back to same address that initially sent.?

Author: libscott#8867
Content: You can do that! But it requires an eval function. Basically, you'll reject any transaction that doesn't wait the waiting period or has an output address different to the input address. CC EVAL conditions allow you to inspect a transaction, and if it's "wrong" you can reject it.

Author: libscott#8867
Content: which means you can constrain transactions to those that are "right" given the rules of your application. Not an easy programming model but it works

Author: polycryptoblog#1173

Author: libscott#8867
Content: @polycryptoblog Not really, except if your address is a p2sh address... You can't restrict receive, but if the address is a p2sh which contains a CC in the redeemscript then you can achieve some kind of send restriction. Depends on the rules you want
